Description: Necklace with amulets: composed of gold beads and amulets and beads of cornelian, steatite and glazed composition. The gold beads are tiny cylinders made from rolled up strips. The very small gold couchant lion amulet is made of gold foil and mounted on a gold cylindrical bead. The gold Ḥeḥ-amulet is made of strips of gold wire soldered together. The figure of the god, who sits with his knees to the right, is a piece of gold foil roughly marked. The hawk amulet with back suspension loop is of cornelian, as are the short truncated convex bicones and the barrel bead. There is a single long cylinder of steatite; the tiny disc beads are of black and grey glazed composition.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Mostagedda, Grave 785 Found at the neck of a female
Curator's comments: Also from this burial: amuletic string (1929,1015.521), beads (1929.1015.521), bracelet with amulets (1929,1015.522), necklaces (1929,1015.517 & 1929,1015.518 ), shell (1929,1015.519). Bibliography: G. Brunton, ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), 99; Tomb register, pl.XLVI; Bead register, pl.XLIX; Bead corpus, pl.LVII, 45K8; 'L'art egyptien au temps des pyramides' (Paris, 1999), pp. 374-375 [202] = 'Egyptian Art in the Age of the Pyramids' (New York, 1999), p. 482 [204].
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (237)
Metropolitan Museum of Art 1999 / Egyptian Art in the Age of the Pyramids (204)
